quoteFirst: At 3.15 a.m. on the 16th August companies began to form up on the tape lines, the assembly being completed by
quoteLast: , when the troops were lying down in the open under a continuous and fairly heavy shell fire and a galling machine-gun fire from the direction of Inverness Copse. About 22 casualties occurred under this fire before zero hour at 5.
title: The War History of the 4th Battalion, the London Regiment (Royal Fusiliers), 1914-1919
author: Grimwade, F. Clive

quoteLast: Lord Melbourne returned. 'Well, Ma'am,' he said, 'we've considered this question, and both the sides of it well, and at last we voted upon it; and there were--the Lord Chancellor for dissolution, Lord Minto[38] for it, Lord Normanby against it, but greatly modified; Lord John for, Lord Palmerston for, Lord Clarendon for, Lord Morpeth for, Lord Lansdowne for, Labouchere for, Hobhouse for, Duncannon[39] for, Baring for, Macaulay for; and under those circumstances of course I felt I could not but go with them.[40] Lord Melbourne was much affected in saying all this.
title: The letters of Queen Victoria, vol. 1, 1837-1843
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Benson, Arthur Christopher, 1862-1925 [Editor]; Esher, Reginald Baliol Brett, Viscount, 1852-1930 [Editor]

quoteFirst: “No; I was only told of the crime at
quoteLast: . Alfred, that’s the footman, came on a bicycle.”
title: In the night
author: Gorell, Ronald Gorell Barnes, Baron, 1884-1963

title: The History of the 7th Battalion Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders
author: Sandilands, James Walter; MacLeod, Norman, 1872-1960

quoteLast: ," said he, "which would correspond to about a quarter to eleven on earth.  As the sun rises at half-past seven, it will be dark about three hours, for the time between dawn and daylight will, of course, be as short as that we have just experienced between sunset and night."
title: A Journey in Other Worlds: A Romance of the Future
author: Astor, John Jacob, 1864-1912

quoteLast: Lord Melbourne returned. 'Well, Ma'am,' he said, 'we've considered this question, and both the sides of it well, and at last we voted upon it; and there were--the Lord Chancellor for dissolution, Lord Minto[38] for it, Lord Normanby against it, but greatly modified; Lord John for, Lord Palmerston for, Lord Clarendon for, Lord Morpeth for, Lord Lansdowne for, Labouchere for, Hobhouse for, Duncannon[39] for, Baring for, Macaulay for; and under those circumstances of course I felt I could not but go with them.[40] Lord Melbourne was much affected in saying all this.
title: The letters of Queen Victoria, vol. 1, 1837-1843

quoteFirst: It spread out like a partly opened fan, its greatest width at the extreme end being about five degrees or more. The nucleus shone brightly as a star of the second magnitude, but by half past three it began to grow less distinct, and at
quoteLast: the comet had faded from view on the arrival of the first few streaks of dawn.
title: The romance of comets
author: Proctor, Mary, 1862-1957

quoteFirst: Another destroyer, the _Reade_, came to the rescue; at
quoteLast: the British salvage tugs, _Revenger_ and _Woonda_ arrived, and at 5:30 o'clock the American tug _Concord_ reached the scene. The _Smith_, which was ordered to take to port all the crew not needed, at 5:20 left for Brest.
title: Our Navy at war
author: Daniels, Josephus, 1862-1948

quoteFirst: Guy Boothby, in the opening sentence of his _Across the World for a Wife_, says, "It was a cold, dreary winter's afternoon, and by the time the hands of the clock on my mantelpiece joined forces and stood at
quoteLast: , my chambers were well-nigh as dark as midnight." It is evident that the author here made a slip, for, as we have seen above, he is 1 min. 49+1/11 sec. out in his reckoning.
title: Amusements in Mathematics
author: Dudeney, Henry Ernest, 1857-1930

quoteFirst: In time of peace, and in the merchant-service, the London price is from a guinea to about seven-and-twenty shillings the calendar month. A common labourer in London, at the rate of nine or ten shillings a week, may earn in the calendar month from
quoteLast: -and-forty shillings. The sailor, indeed, over and above his pay, is supplied with provisions. Their value, however, may not perhaps always exceed the difference between his pay and that of the common labourer; and though it sometimes should, the excess will not be clear gain to the sailor, because he cannot share it with his wife and family, whom he must maintain out of his wages at home.
title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations
author: Smith, Adam, 1723-1790
